In general, slight variability among the specimens regading overall size, orientation of zygapophyses, and variable development of heamal 'keels' and neural spines show that the specimens pertain to different portions of the body. In any case, all of the specimens are similar enough to Coniophis trunk vertebrae described and illustrated elsewhere by numerous authors (e.g., Marsh, 1892; Gilmore, 1938; Fox, 1975; Rage, 1998; Holman, 2000; Longrich et al., 2012b; Nydam, 2013; Smith, 2013; Caldwell et al., 2015) that further detailed description here is unnecessary. However, only one of the study specimens (TMM 45947-554) exhibits a pronounced haemal 'keel' as in the holotype (USNM 2134 , Marsh, 1892 Gilmore, 1938) so both presumably belong to the anteriormost trunk. Others appear more like Coniophis sp. from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation of northern Mexico (SEPCP 18/201, 202; Aguillon-Martínez, 2010, fig. 11) where the keel is reduced suggesting that it pertains to a more posterior position. In any case, the form of the haemal keel and associated central bony ridge on trunk vertebrae in C. precedence is positionally variable (Longrich, 2012b; Caldwell et al., 2015) ; hence, not diagnostically useful as applied to the holotype of 'Coniophis cosgriffi' from New Mexico (MNA PL 1612; Armstrong-Zeigler, 1978) . Furthermore, none of our specimens exhibit a comparatively narrow, protruding zygosphene or comparatively elevated neural ridge as in 'C. cosgriffi'. We also refer the reader to Holman (2000) for additional comments regarding Armstrong-Zeigler's referral and agree that MNA PL 1612 likely does not pertain to Coniophis. Remarks. Coniophis is the only "anilioid" taxon recognized in the Late Cretaceous North American fossil record (Smith, 2013) ; however, our referral of specimens to aff. Coniophis is a very cautious one. "Anilioid" snakes are predominantly burrowing species whose trunk vertebrae may be broadly characterized, for example, by depressed, saddle-shaped neural arches, low or absent neural spines, and high-angled prezygapophyses among others (Smith, 2013; Head, 2015) . The fragmentary nature of the Lowerverse snake specimens and their partial obscuration by matrix precludes a definitive referral. However, they concord in form and size with Coniophis reported from elsewhere from the Late Cretaceous Westertn Interior of North America. That being said, we also recognize that Coniophis (sensu lato) may represent a wastebasket taxon for "fossorial ecomorphs" (Head and Holroyd, 2008) and we agree with Head (2015) that snake vertebral morphology may have limited value as it relates to the referral of similar vertebral specimens to this seemingly generalized form genus (see Head and Holroyd, 2008; Smith, 2013; Head, 2015 for useful discussions in this regard). In any case, given the local depositional context and admixture of species within the Lowerverse deposits, it is exceedingly unlikey that these specimens pertain to just a single animal and much more likely that multiple individuals of aff. Coniophis sp. are represented. It is also possible that they represent multiple, closely-related species.
SQUAMATA Oppel, 1811 incertae sedis.
Species 1 (Fig. 9H, I ).
Referred Specimen. TMM 45947-550 (right fragmentary maxilla)

Description. This fragmentary specimen is otherwise wellpreserved and pertains to a medial right maxilla. It does not appear to have been digested as have other specimens in the Lowervese collection (e.g., interminate squamate Species 2 below). The generally conical crown is pleurodont, and somewhat wider mesiodistally than labiolingually. It lacks ornamentation. Cementum is absent. What remains of the maxillary posterior process suggests that it was low and ascended abruptly. Although a portion of the facial process is missing, it seemingly was not very elevated. Two foramina are present on the labial surface; however, the lingual side of the specimen is damaged and nothing remains of the palatine process. On a small portion of the entrance to the superior alveolar canal remains.

Remarks. TMM 45947-550 is so fragmentary that it cannot be readily compared to other forms. Superficially, the preserved crown in TMM 45947-550 is similar to the blunt conical teeth described in the dentary of the Early Cretaceous, European taxon Saurillus obtusus (Estes, 1983; Evans et al., 2012) . Furthermore, its low posterior maxillary process is akin to that in Hypostylos gen. nov. Both TMM 45947-550 and Hypostylos similarly exhibit rather robust teeth. However, they are considerably disparate in form; teeth in Hypostylos are columnar and low crowned while that in TMM 45947-550 is conical and extends considerably further past the dental parapet. In any case, both Hypostylos and Saurillus are scincomorphs so perhaps TMM 45947-550 is likewise related.
SQUAMATA Oppel, 1811 incertae sedis.
Species 2 (Fig. 9J ).
Referred Specimen. TMM 45947-551 (indeterminate jaw fragment).

Description. TMM 45947-551 exhibits smooth, low, and unornamented crowns. Exposure of the pulp cavity suggests some degree of post-mortem erosion due to transport. However, as in other specmeins within the Lowerverse collection, the lingual surface of the specimen is well-preserved. Thus, it is also possible that they were digested prior to burial (e.g., see the indeterminate borioteiioidean described above). Teeth are rather broad mesiodistally. They are closely spaced and (where unobscured by matrix) join just above their points of attachment. In lingual aspect the tooth shafts are oddly irregular; one is almost sinuous in appearance (Fig. 9J) . Furthermore, tooth bases are labiolingually expanded forming a buttress on the dental lamina. Careful examination of the specimen (after imaging) revealed that a replacement pit had formed directly below the shaft of the centermost tooth; however, it is largely obscured by matrix. The subdental lamina is fractured and so the width of the sulcus dentalis cannot be determined but it seems to have been shallow.

Remarks. TMM 45947-551 has stout teeth suggestive of myrmecophagy (R. Nydam pers. comm.) or an otherwise durophagous diet. It is likely that this peculiar specimen pertains to a taxon other than described elsewhere herein from Lowerverse.
SQUAMATA Oppel, 1811 incertae sedis.
Species 3 (Fig. 9K, L) Referred Specimen. TMM 45947-552 (right medial dentary fragment).

Description. This indeterminate squamate consists of a right medial dentary fragment bearing three complete teeth (Fig. 9K, L) . This fragmentary specimen is otherwise well-preserved and does not exhibit signs of digestive corrosion (e.g., exposed pulp cavities) as in indeterminate squamate Species 2 (above). The teeth are fully pleurodont with smooth, slightly recurved crowns extending about 1/3 of their length beyond the lateral parapet. Basal cementum is absent. Crowns vary slightly in appearance but all are labiolingually compressed and have a minor lingual deflection. As preserved, tooth bases are rather wide mesiodistally which gives the teeth a triangular outline in lingual view. The teeth contact each other about >1/3 of their distance above the subdental lamina. The lamina is shallow but moderately wide with a poorly developed sulcus dentalis. The remnant of the ventrolabial surface of the dentary suggests that Meckel's canal was open medially in this portion of the element and it is separated from the inferior alveolar canal by a thin lamina of bone.

Remarks. The teeth in TMM 45947-552 are smooth, closely spaced, and triangular in lingual view as in similarly-aged and Kaiparowits Formation Morphotype G (KFmG) (Nydam, 2013) and 'Alocosaurus johnstoni' (Gao, 1992) . However; they are not recurved and subpleurodont as in KFmG, nor are they nearly subacrodont as in 'A. Johnstoni'. Moreover, both of these forms have comparatively deeper subdental laminae so it is very unlikely that TMM 45947-552 pertains to either one. However, in several ways this morph most resembles the enigmatic holotype of 'Lanceosaurus hatcheri' (USNM 10701; Gilmore, 1928 ; see Gao and Fox, 1996 for a discussion) given that it similarly bears transversely compressed teeth with wide bases and smooth, obtusely pointed crowns. TMM occlusal and (L) lingual views. Small circles indicate presumed anterior direction of specimen. Abbreviations: (fpr) facial process; (lab) labial foramen; (pmp) post maxillary process; (rep) replacement tooth. Common scale bar for A-G ¼ 1 mm; all other scale bars ¼ .5 mm. 45947-552 differs from USNM 10701 in that it seemingly has a shallower subdental lamina, exhibits teeth which are pleurodont in attachment rather than in the subpleurodont manner alluded to in USNM 10701 by Gilmore (1928) , and has a comparatively more open Meckel's canal as in chamopsiids (Estes, 1964; Gao and Fox, 1996) . Indeed, USNM 10701 was synonymized with Chamops segnis by Estes (1964, p. 108) who interpreted the absence of crown ornamentation ostensibly as the result of digestive erosion but otherwise likened it to that taxon. In this case, we find no apparent evidence of digestive erosion. The broad mesiodistal bases and pleurodont teeth in this specimen also suggest that there were comparatively few, large teeth in the dental arcade as in some (non-amblyodont) Late Cretaceous and Paleogene amphisbaenians (e.g., Smith, 2009a; Folie et al., 2013; Cernansky et al., 2015; Longrich et al., 2015; Berkovitz and Shellis, 2017) . Indeed, TMM 45947-552 does exhibit teeth similar to some amphisbaenians (e.g., Blanus) which similarly has conical, weakly recurved teeth with labiolingually compressed crowns (Georgalis et al., 2018) . In any case, TMM 45947-552 likely pertains to a taxon other than described elsewhere herein from Lowerverse.

Along with the Lowerverse local fauna, two other notable Campanian microverterate localities have been reported in the Aguja Formation. Both of these are situated within lower portion of the overlying (Judithian age) upper shale member and have produced similar diverse coastal faunas as at Lowerverse including numerous squamates (Rowe et al., 1992; Sankey, 1998 Sankey, , 2005 Sankey, , 2008 Nydam et al., 2013) . The first of these, the Terlingua local fauna (Rowe et al., 1992) , was collected from a locality just outside of the town of Terlingua, TX very near Big Bend National Park and the second, the Talley Mountain local fauna (Sankey, 1998) , from near Talley Mountain within the park itself (Fig. 1) . Although geographically somewhat disparate (ca. 37 km apart), these two sites are situated at nearly the same stratigraphic interval within the lowermost upper shale and both are comprised of coastal marsh and swamp deposits. However, these facies are not as well developed at either locality as at Lowerverse (Lehman, 1985a; Davies and Lehman, 1989; Rowe et al., 1992; Sankey, 1998 Sankey, , 2008 Lehman et al., 2019) . All three Aguja localities have similarly produced microfossils derived from lenticular conglomerates.

In spite of their apparent temporal and depositional equivalence, the three localities above have yielded considerably dissimilar numbers of squamate fossils and few conspecific taxa. The reason for this incongruity is unclear; however, 1) sampling bias involving collection techniques and 2) morphological interpretation involving very fragmentary specimens have likely had significant effects regarding their currently recognized taxonomic consistencies. Whatever the case, these three localities have produced diverse assemblages which collectively represent a reasonable account of the squamate taxa present within a relatively narrow, early-middle Campanian stratigraphic interval (Fig. 1) . These circumstances provide a useful opportunity to study the temporal transition of southern squamate faunas having developed locally and within corresponding environs. For the sake of convenience, the two upper shale microfossil assemblages will be referred to collectively as the 'upper shale fauna' in the following discussion. However, due to their ambiguous affinities, the three indeterminate lizards (Squamata incertae sedis Species 1, 2, and 3) described herein from the Lowerverse fauna will not be included.

The Lowerverse squamate fauna contains as many as 11 scincomorphan taxa. Compared to the upper shale, at least five are exclusive to the lower shale (Bothriagenys mysterion, B. flectomendax sp. nov., Hydrargysaurus gladius gen. et sp. nov., aff. Socognathus Species 1 and 2 (Table 1) . On the other hand, the upper shale contains as few as eight scincomorphans with only two unique taxa (Peneteius sp. and Chamops sp.). Here, like Nydam et al. (2013) , we regard the referral of LSUMG 140:1604 to Chamops to be inconclusive as figured by Sankey (1998 fig. 1.21E, 2008 fig. 5.3.26) ; however, we feel that the specimen likely pertains to Chamopsiidae. This tentative referral is further supported by the three seeming chamopsiids described herein establishing the likely presence of chamopsiids at Lowerverse. If so, apart from the three indeterminate chamopsiids described herein, the upper shale fauna has conclusively produced but a single unique scincomorphan e Peneteius; a taxon also reported from the late Campanian Cerro del Pueblo Formation of Northern Mexico (Aguillon-Martínez, 2010). Conversely, three scincomorphan forms are credibly shared between both faunas including the likely xantusiid Catactegenys solaster, the indeterminate scincomorphan Apsgnathus triptodon, as well as at least one indeterminate chamopsiid (we note that three chamopsiids are seemingly present at Lowerverse and so one or two of these are likely distinct from the one reported from the upper shale). A fourth taxon, Hypostylos lehmani, may also be present in both faunas if our tentative referral of Sankey's (1998 Sankey's ( , 2008 indeterminate 'glyptosaurine' specimen (LSUMG 140:6106) is correct. Otherwise it would represent an additional species exclusive to the lower shale.
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: The collective array of anguimorphs is more difficult to assess because specimens are either relatively rare or too fragmentary to characterize. In spite of the unconfirmed xenosaur described above, anguimorphs are principally represented in the Lowerverse local fauna by possibly as many as three varanoids. Copious remains pertaining to one of these (D. shilleri) suggests that it was a dominant mesopredator within the local environment (Wick et al., 2015) . Anguimorphs in the upper shale fauna are more diverse. Aside from the questionable presence of an inderminate glyptosaurine (LSUMG 140:6106; Sankey, 1998 Sankey, , 2008  informally referred herein to the scincomorph H. lehmani gen.et sp. nov.), anguimorphs are convincingly represented by three forms including the anguid Odaxosaurus piger, a likely xenosaurid, as well as (poorly represented) varanoids such as cf. Parasaniwa wyomingensis (although it is possible that this species is also among the indeterminate varanoids also reported from Lowereverse). Interestingly, unlike the Lowerverse assemblage, varanoid remains are comparatively rare at Terlingua and absent at Talley Mountain. The presence of cf. Coniophis at Lowerverse is analogous to the Terlingua locality where a similarly diminutive, but indeterminate snake (represented by fragmentary jaws) is also present. Snakes were not found at Talley Mountain. Overall, the Aguja Formation exhibits a marked reduction in lizard diversity from early to middle Campanian time.
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: 5.2. Squamate diversity within a paracontemporaneous faunal complex from Utah e a 'southern' analog Diversity in modern faunas can be measured using a variety of mathematical indices (e.g., Simpson and Shannon, dominance, evenness, etc.). However, use of these can be problematic when applied to the fossil record as bias involving sampling and preservation often makes it unfeasible to obtain an accurate taxonomic inventory. Conclusions based upon fragmentary specimens ascribed to ostensibly 'known' taxa can also be unreliable. In the realm of microvertebrate paleontology, a comprehensive inventory of all species present at a specific location may be an almost unattainable goal in practical applications. However, in spite of these difficulties, the following manifest taxonomic differences between separate squamate faunas within southern Laramidia are almost certainly sending meaningful ecological signals.
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: Both the Wahweap and Kaiparowits formations of Utah are similar to the Aguja Formation in that they; 1) are within the southern biogeographic province of the Late Cretaceous Western Interior, 2) have been sampled extensively and, 3) have produced numerous squamate specimens from broadly comparable Campanian intervals and environs (see comprehensive inventory of Nydam, 2013) . The Wahweap Formation (in part Aquilan in age) exhibits remarkably lower squamate diversity (three taxa) than the lower shale member of the Aguja Formation at Lowerverse (also Aquilan) where as many as 18 taxa are present. However, the somewhat younger (Judithian) Kaiparowits Formation (as many as 21 taxa) is somewhat more speciose than Lowerverse. However, it is much more so than the (combined) lizard fauna produced from the similarly-aged, basal portion of the Aguja upper shale member exposed at Terlingua and Talley Mountain (10 taxa). The decrease in lizard diversity observed in the early-middle Campanian Aguja Formation is at odds with that seen in southern Utah where, over the same period, lizard diversity markedly increased. As one would expect to see similar temporal patterns of diversity emege within similar regional biomes, it is likely that these disparities relate to factors other than time.
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: A direct comparison between the squamate assemblages from the Wahweap, Kapairowits and Aguja formations reveals numerous species which are apparently unique to each sub-province. Apart from indeterminate forms and simple morphotypes (or those involving speculative taxonomy which otherwise would only increase their respective formational diversities), by one extensive account (Nydam, 2013) , the Wahweap-Kapairowits squamate complex contains the following genera unique to southern Utah:
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: Mensicognathus, Palaeoscincosaurus, Tripennaculus, and ?Exostinus. On the other hand, The Aguja Formation lower-upper shale squamate complex contains the following genera unique to West Texas: Apsgnathus, Catactegenys, Dryadissector, Hydrargysaurus, and Hypostylos (Rowe et al., 1992; Sankey, 1998 Sankey, , 2005 Sankey, , 2008 Nydam et al., 2013 , the present report). However, both complexes share: Bothriagenys, Coniophis, Odaxosaurus, Parasaniwa, Penetius, and quite possibly chamopsiids such as Chamops and/or Leptochamops. It is also likely that a number of these genera may include unique, sub-provincial species as does Bothriagenys (B. mysterion of southern Utah versus B. flectomendax of West Texas). Although the diminutive snake Coniophis is present in all three formations, it is represented by vertebrae so it is possible that several "anilioid" species are present. Snakes are not known from north of approximately 45 north during the late Campanian so they appear to have been restricted to southern Laramidia (Nydam et al., 2013) . With as many as 10 individuals represented at Lowerverse, Coniophis seems to also have been comparatively more abundant here than elsewhere in southern Laramidia. However, its presence in considerably older (AlbianeCenomanian) strata in southern Utah (Gardner and Cifelli, 1999) thus far suggests a northerly origin and southern dispersal for the species. However, it now seems that small fossorial snakes like Coniophis were well established in southernmost Laramidia by early Campanian time e somewhat earlier than implied by various late Campanian occurrences (Armstrong-Ziegler, 1978; Aguillon-Martínez, 2010; Nydam, 2013) . The above differences involving southern intra-provincial diversity are noteworthy. Certainly, these differences would be even more pronounced if the many (obviously distinctive) indeterminate squamate morphtypes described from southern Utah and West Texas were included as part of the present discussion.
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: Hence, even on a sub-provincial scale, it is clear that significant disparities can be shown to exist regarding the taxonomic make-up of temporally-overlapping formations comprised of facies representing generally analogous pericoastal environments. Climatic variation within the Western Interior Basin is the most reasonable explanation for the overarching, biogeographic patterns regarding Table 1 Comparison of squamate assemblages recovered from the three Aguja Formation microsites described in the text. Bold denotes taxa likely representing individual species. Abbreviations in parentheses apply to respective collecting localities shown in Figure 1 . divergent late Campanian vertebrate faunas throughout Laramidia (e.g., Lehman, 1997 Lehman, , 2001 Gates et al., 2010) . Why opposing trends involving overall Campanian squamate diversity co-occurred in southern Utah and West Texas is unknown. By middle Campanian time, a long-term period of global cooling was underway culminating in Cretaceous temperature minima during the Maastrichtian (Huber et al., 1995) . The result was a progressive drop in sea level along with rapid easterly progradation of the shoreline of the Western Interior Seaway. During the Late Cretaceous, eustatic influences are thought to have played an increasingly significant role concerning the isolation, dispersal, and diversification of some vertebrate clades (e.g., Loewen et al., 2013) .
body_text.section: Lowerverse lizard fauna compared with that from the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation

body_text.text: The Lowerverse squamate assemblage contains as many as 11 scincomorphs with three of these (Hypostylos lehmani gen. et sp. nov., Bothriagenys flectomendax, sp. nov., and Hydrargysaurus gladius gen. et sp. nov.) pertaining to new taxa. Anguimorphs are also well-represented as is a Coniophis-like snake. The occurrence of several additional indeterminate lizards (all unique to Lowerverse) completes this diverse southern squamate fauna. During early to middle Campanian time, stark taxonomic differences observed among squamates from somewhat younger strata of West Texas as well as paracontemporaneous strata of southern Utah indicate that squamate communities evolved differently in both areas. Campanian Laramidian ecosystems appear to have been characterized by high beta diversity and basin-scale endemism among some vertebrate species with evidence for higher-order segregation of these into northern and southern provinces (e.g., Lehman, 1997 Lehman, , 2001 Gates et al., 2010; Sampson et al., 2010; Loewen et al., 2013; contra Vavrek and Larson, 2010) . The current work reveals that similar, latitudinally-arrayed quarters of endemism also existed among sub-provincial squamate faunas within the southern biogeographic province of the Western Interior.

Diagnosis. Similar to Bothriagenys mysterion in having Meckel's
canal moderately wide posteriorly but ventrally open as a narrow
slit for most of the length of dentary; having narrow, conical,
TABREF0.text: Differs from B. mysterion in having subpleurodont teeth that become shorter as they trend distally; having a distally displaced cuspis labialis which results in cristae mesialis and distalis of unequal lengths giving the tooth the false appearance of being recurved; having longer culmina lateris; and having conspicuous striae on all lingual facets of the crown (see original diagnosis for Bothriagenys inNydam, 2002 regarding morphological differences between the holotype and extant forms).

TABREF1.text: that Paramacellodus sp. has anterior and posterior striae dominans that are more closely spaced than in KFmA or Bothriagenys and, unlike in Paramacellodus sp. where Meckel's canal is open lingually along the entire posterior portion of the dentary. In Bothriagenys, Meckel's canal appears as a narrow, ventrally-open slot throughout most of its trend along the jaw. In spite of these differences, there are enough morphological similarities to suggest possible affinities among these taxa. The presence of B. mysterion and B. flectomendax in the Aguja Formation represents the first definitive record of two co-occurring species of Bothriagenys in the Western Interior of North America.If B. mysterion and Kaiparowits Formation Morphotype A of Utah indeed represent the same taxon as implied byNydam (2013) and reported here (and in spite of their temporal separation), similar co-occurrences involving Bothriagenys likely occurred elsewhere in Laramidia during the Late Cretaceous.

TABREF2.content:
Holotype. TMM 45947-533 (medial left dentary fragment with
teeth).
Referred Specimens. TMM 45947-534, -535, -536 (dentary and
premaxillary fragments with teeth).
Locality. TMM 45947; middle of the lower shale member of the
Aguja Formation, Brewster County, Texas.
Diagnosis. Differs from Bothriagenys and other scincomorphs in
having the following unique combination of characteristics
including; 1) possessing weakly tricuspid crowns, 2) lacking a
distinct pars furcata, 3) having atypically long culmina lateris on the
lingual surface of the tooth shaft, 4) possessing a shallow, broad
subdental lamina, and 5) having a ventrally open Meckel's canal
that is not slot-like.
TABREF2.text: ).Etymology. Derived from Greek hydrargyros (water silver) in reference to the many abandoned mercury mines near the type locality and Greek sauros (lizard). Type and Only Species. Hydrargysaurus gladius, sp. nov. Diagnosis. As for the type and only known species.Hydrargysaurus gladius sp. nov.Etymology. Latin gladius references the teeth of this taxon which (in lingual view) resemble the blade of an ancient Roman sword.
